title: How can I edit a message I have received, in order to make it more useful in my archive?
content: As an example, I might order a flashlight from a vendor. I would have received an order confirmation by email, and then might get another message when it is delivered. But depending on the vendor's practices, these messages might not say "flashlight." A year later, suppose I want to know where I ordered the flashlight. If the messages refer to an order number but do not say "flashlight", I don't have a simple way to find this out. What I would like to do, when I archive the message (or subsequently), is to edit the body (or subject) to include this keyword. Is there any straightforward way to do this in Thunderbird? Thanks for any advice.
creator: taxpayer

content:
I had to reinstall Windows 10.

My old email was via a POP3 connection. Thunderbird required me to create a new account before it would open. I have pointed the profiles.ini to my old folder, but when Thunderbird opens, it opens the newly created email with an IMAP connection.

This is my changed profiles.ini file. Can you see anything wrong with it?

[InstallD78BF5DD33499EC2] Default=Profiles/yhq1qhem.default-release Locked=1

[Profile1] Name=default IsRelative=0 Path="E:\Thunderbird\Profiles\o8f5qusr.default" Default=1

[Profile0] Name=default-release IsRelative=1 Path=Profiles/yhq1qhem.default-release

[General] StartWithLastProfile=1 Version=2

Thanks for your help. I really need to access my old emails.

Thanks, Rae

title: Different methods to export Thunderbird email to Outlook?
content: Mozilla Thunderbird and Microsoft Outlook are two popular email applications that support IMAP accounts. While Thunderbird is user-friendly, it lacks a built-in calendar and has integration constraints, which pushes customers to migrate from Thunderbird to Outlook. Microsoft Outlook, a vital Office tool, excels in terms of functionality, solid security, Office 365 integration, and cross-platform compatibility, making it a popular choice for businesses. Because of Outlook's additional capabilities, including increased email security, task automation, and cross-platform flexibility, businesses prefer Thunderbird to Outlook migration. The manual migration method is risky in terms of data loss and complexity, but the Mozilla Thunderbird Backup Tool provides an easy-to-use option that ensures effective data conversion and smooth export to multiple email clients. With the help of this tool, you can effortlessly export Thunderbird emails to Outlook. Explore our website to learn more about the tool's features and capabilities.
creator: aqeelahmadsaifi2468

title: Thunderbird Activity Monitor shows index processing stuck
content:
Problem Opening the Activity Manager is opened (Tools > Actvity Manager), then getting messages, the indexing process appears and remains stuck with no progress, never ending. In my case, stuck on some inbox (I have several accounts) at 15%.

I searched for a direct fix to find none, until I asked Google this question: "Why does Thunderbird index messages?"

The question gave this result: Title: Rebuilding the Global Database "[https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/.../rebuilding-global-database]".

I saw that article referred to a global database file for Thunderbird. To rebuild it requires the deletion of the database file. I did that and the "stuck indexing" issue got fixed.

So here is the fix to this "stuck indexing issue" for Thunderbird.

FIX

  1. Close Thunderbird completely.
  2. Locate your Thunderbird Profile folder. It is usually at:

C:\Users\(User Name)\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles

  1. Locate this database file: "global-messages-db.sqlite" in each profile.
  2. Delete the database file. If you have several profiles, do the same in each one.
  3. Open Thunderbird
  4. Open Activity Manager, and shortly, Thunderbird will show itself indexing messages to rebuild the Global index. This time, it will complete. If it doesn't automatically start, click "Get Messages" and that should kickstart it.

Cause of issue? Likely a corrupt database file.
creator: Mark2012

title: Grouped folders with IMAP are at least / but only temporarily possible
content: Hello, I read somewhere that grouped folders were not possible with IMAP accounts. But with Win 11, TB 115.6.0 (64-bit) they definetly CAN be created and they are ALSO DISPLAYED (see pic). In order to display folders even more specifically, after that you can also make individual grouped folders favorite folders and display them as such. ONE / THE ONLY PROBLEM: If you close TB and open it again, those (and even no) folders are displayed anymore. However, the grouped folders and their settings are still there and will (only) be displayed again if you check the appropriate box for their display. I hope that it's not that difficult - and would be excellent - to implement so that the grouped folders and favorite folders (and also the "normal" or all previously displayed folders) and their view are just displayed unchanged even after restarting TB. So, in the simplest case, it's just a matter of the appropriate checking of the box for the folders display are set "automatically" when you restart TB / the computer (at least for the grouped folders, but keeping the Favorites folder would also be good, of course). In addition, after restarting TB, you wouldn't be shocked that all email accounts or folders seem to have disappeared. Could this be FIXED / IMPLEMENTED PLEASE? Then TB would be perfect! Thanks in advance. Pat
creator: misc.trash

title: system help
content:
It isn't a question I'm afraid, but an observation. I am getting ready to finally leave thunderbird behind.

I've been with TB since windows stopped their IE many years ago. The first few years were good - hence small donations now & then.

I'm now a disabled pensioner & need to rely on my electronic items. Also, I can't keep up with TB constant stoppage of accounts "New passord needed" etc, which, when we could get contact with them, was told "taint us mate,,, must be the Microsoft", but upon checking, there was never, ever a problem with MS. It's got to the point where I can't get access to half of my accounts, or can get access to some, but not send,,,, or receive messages,,,, etc etc.

Now I can't get contact with them for help. I would have thought, someone in this business would have a direct email address where we can ask specific questions.

If I can't get help to use your product, it's a shame & I'm seeking an alternative.

content:

title: No Saved Paasswords.  TB prompts for new password entry but never displays the password entry screen/field
content:

Now when TB tries to send login information a screen comes up saying "... Sending of password for user xxxxx@xxxx.xxx did not succeed. Clicking OK brings up Retry/Enter New Password/Cancel pop up. When clicking Enter New Password option, field to enter new password does not pop up.

Have deleted an account an reentered it but still have problem.

Any help?

6 other computers at my home are working fine with TB though at first they had the same problem. I just retied and eventually it worked but not on this, my primary computer.

title: inbox MESSAGE COUNT is doubled
content:
Here's my problem, when a new message arrives in my inbox the inbox MESSAGE COUNT double counts the message. If one new message comes in the inbox COUNT says '2'. If two new messages come in the inbox COUNT says '4'.

>NOTE:< There are NOT double (duplicate) messages in the inbox, ONLY the inbox message COUNT is double.

Absolutely everything else about Thunderbird (INCLUDING ALL OTHER FOLDER COUNTS; for example, drafts, trash, sent, etc.) works perfectly fine. Only the inbox COUNT is screwed up. I've looked around this site and have not seen the same problem or a solution. Thanks to anyone who can help.
